moves.1. e4: Kings Gambit game. Opening that has always fascinated me. Hope you find the game of some interest.   Please feel free to comment.
moves.4. exd5 Nf6 5. Bb5+: Prob most stern test in this line.
moves.5... c6: best move as 5... K(b)d7  6. c4, a6. 7. Bxd7+, Bxd7. 8. 0-0   Leave white with an advantage.
moves.6. dxc6 bxc6: This move is quite commonly played although Kc6 seems stronger.
moves.7. Bc4: Be2 is an alternative which allows white to advance central pawns.
moves.7... Nd5: Alternative is Bd6 which white should prob reply with Qe2+.
moves.8. O-O: Maybe Nc3 is better? This would stop black developing Bishop to d6 and make f pawn even weaker.
moves.8... Bd6: Against Be6 white should play Bb3 with the idea c4 & d4
moves.9. Nc3 Be6: If black castles white can attack d5
moves.10. Ne4 Be7: Obviously black wanted to keep bishop but this move means he can only defend f4 using extreme measures
moves.11... O-O 12. d4 Nd7 13. Qe2: White is looking like winning a pawn by c4
moves.13... g5: ?  13....Re8, 14. c4, Bf8! 15. cxNd5, Bxd5. 16.N(f)d2, f5. 17. Rxf4, fe. 18. Rxe4, Nf4 gives black compensation but white still has the better of it and would have been far more fun :)
moves.14. c4 Nd5b6 15. h4: ! White starts to open up Kingside
moves.16. hxg5 hxg5 17. Nfxg5: White wins 2 pawns in exchange for knight. White also permanently damages blacks pawn defense and is able to get more pieces into the Kingside to attack.
moves.17... Bxg5 18. Bxf4 Bf6: exchanging both would leave black totally exposed.
moves.19. Rad1: protecting pawn and getting him into the action
moves.19... Bf5 20. Be5: White is happy to exchange all minor pieces as it will allow the big guns into do a number on blacks King
